item.title: Tata Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Out Investors in Resurgent
item.description: Tata Group is in talks to buy out other shareholders in Resurgent Power Ventures Pte, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Baiju Kalesh, Sanjai P R

media:content.media:description: The production line at the Tata Power Co. 4.3 GW Solar Cell and Module Manufacturing Plant in Tirunelveli, India. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

item.title: India’s E-Commerce Stocks Outrun Chinese Peers on Profit Hopes
item.description: India’s top e-commerce stocks have outpaced local indexes and regional peers over the past month, as a rapid rebound fuels bets on their ability to edge out rivals and boost profitability.
item.dc:creator: Diksha Rajput

media:content.media:description: A Swiggy delivery worker in Mumbai. Photographer: Abeer Khan/Bloomberg

item.title: AirPod Maker Luxshare Is Said to Pick Banks for HK Listing
item.description: Luxshare Precision Industry Co. is working with China International Capital Corp., Citic Securities Co. and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. on its planned Hong Kong listing, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti, Dong Cao

media:content.media:description: Luxshare helps make Apple AirPods

item.title: US Lifts Chip Design Curbs On China as Part of Trade Deal
item.description: The Trump administration has lifted export license requirements for chip design software sales in China, as Washington and Beijing implement a trade deal for both countries to ease recent restrictions on critical technologies.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: Siemens AG. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Tesla’s Sales Fall But Investor Support Stays Strong | Bloomberg Tech 7/2/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss the drop in Tesla’s second-quarter sales. Plus, Foxconn pulls Chinese workers from India in a blow to Apple. And, Microsoft plans a second large round of layoffs as it looks to spend more on artificial intelligence. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oracle, OpenAI Expand Stargate Deal for More US Data Centers
item.description: OpenAI has agreed to rent a massive amount of computing power from Oracle Corp. data centers as part of its Stargate initiative, underscoring the intense requirements for cutting-edge artificial intelligence products.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford, Rachel Metz

media:content.media:description: The Oracle offices in Redwood City, California.

item.title: MARA's Thiel Sees Huge Institutional Interest in Bitcoin
item.description: MARA CEO Fred Thiel discusses the demand for crypto, the state of the Bitcoin-mining industry and MARA's business strategy with Carol Massar and Matt Miller on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: SoftBank Sells $4.2 Billion in Dollar, Euro Bonds Amid AI Push
item.description: SoftBank Group Corp. priced $4.2 billion of bonds in dollars and euros Wednesday, as the technology investment firm turns to global debt markets to accelerate its push into artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga, Ronan Martin

media:content.media:description: A SoftBank Corp. store in Yamato, Japan.

item.title: Microsoft Makes Deep Job Cuts Across Xbox Division, Cancels Games
item.description: Hundreds of people were laid off as the company canceled upcoming games such as Perfect Dark and Everwild
item.dc:creator: Jason Schreier

media:content.media:description: An Xbox games controller

item.title: Six Observations From Summer Game Fest
item.description: E3 is no more, but June is still a good time for new video games
item.dc:creator: Jason Schreier

media:content.media:description: Onimusha: Way of the Sword was one of the many games demonstrated at this year’s Summer Game Fest

item.title: Uber-Backed Moove Raising $1.2 Billion in Debt for Expansion
item.description: African ride-hailing startup Moove is close to raising $1.2 billion in a debt round that will help it finance a rollout of an autonomous-driving fleet with Alphabet Inc.’s Waymo and expand in the US, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: Waymo cars at a Waymo facility.

item.title: TikTok Cuts More Workers From US E-Commerce Division
item.description: TikTok is cutting more workers from its US e-commerce division, TikTok Shop, the third round of layoffs for that team since April.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: TikTok Shop and logo displayed on screens in Guildford, south of London on April 17, 2025.

item.title: US Probes Whether Negotiator Took Slice of Hacker Payments
item.description: Law enforcement officials are investigating a former employee of a company that negotiates with hackers and facilitates cryptocurrency payments during ransomware attacks, according to a statement from the firm, DigitalMint.
item.dc:creator: Jake Bleiberg

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk past the US Department of Justice headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: AI-Made Misinformation Intensifies Iran-Israel Propaganda Fight
item.dc:creator: Daniel Zuidijk

item.title: Sperm Freezing Is a New Hot Market for Startups
item.description: Legacy and Fellow take sperm samples by mail for analysis and preservation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Popescu

item.title: Intralot Has Buyers for Share Capital Hike After Bally’s Deal
item.description: Intralot has received commitments from investors for its upcoming €400 million ($470.6 million) share sale, a move that comes after it agreed to buy Bally’s Interactive International business, the company’s incoming chief executive officer said.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

media:content.media:description: The Ballys Resort in Atlantic City, New Jersey.

item.title: Foxconn Pulls Chinese Staff From India in Hurdle for Apple
item.description: Foxconn Technology Group has asked hundreds of Chinese engineers and technicians to return home from its iPhone factories in India, dealing a blow to Apple Inc.’s manufacturing push in the South Asian country.
item.dc:creator: Sankalp Phartiyal, Debby Wu, Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Foxconn Technology Group's campus in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Foxconn Asks Chinese Workers to Leave India and Go Home
item.description: Foxconn Technology Group has asked hundreds of Chinese engineers and technicians to return home from its iPhone factories in India, dealing a blow to Apple Inc.’s manufacturing push in the South Asian country. It's not clear why Foxconn is doing this. Mandeep Singh of Bloomberg Intelligence is on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Microsoft Cuts 9,000 Workers in Second Wave of Major Layoffs
item.description: Microsoft Corp. began job cuts that will impact about 9,000 workers, its second major wave of layoffs this year as it seeks to control costs while ramping up on artificial intelligence spending.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford, Matt Day

media:content.media:description: A Microsoft store in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

item.title: Thoma Bravo Is in Talks to Acquire Verint Systems
item.description: Buyout firm Thoma Bravo is in talks to acquire Verint Systems Inc., a maker of call center software, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: ‘South Park’ Season Debut Delayed With Streaming Rights in Limbo
item.description: Comedy Central has delayed the upcoming debut of the new season of South Park, prompting a vitriolic response from the show’s creators.
item.dc:creator: Lucas Shaw

media:content.media:description: South Park characters in Beverly Hills, California.

item.title: Apple, Alphabet and Tesla are Holding the S&P 500 Rally Back
item.description: Investors may be tempted to imagine how much higher the S&P 500 Index would be if three of its most influential stocks weren’t lagging behind.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: Honor Looks to Outshine Samsung with Extremely Thin Foldable Phone
item.description: Chinese hardware brand Honor announced a slimmer foldable phone, a bid to out-design Samsung Electronics Co. days before it launches its own new foldable devices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Welch

media:content.media:description: Honor’s Magic V5 foldable phone.

item.title: Microsoft’s Job Cuts Point to Squeeze From Rising Expense of AI
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Brody Ford reports on the rising artificial intelligence spending.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford

media:content.media:description: The Microsoft Corp. booth at the Hannover Messe 2025 trade fair in Hannover, Germany, on Monday, March 31, 2025. German inflation slowed more than anticipated in March, nearing the European Central Bank's 2% target as officials ponder whether to lower interest rates again at their next meeting or pause.

item.title: Trillion-Dollar Pools of Capital Mask Middle East VC Paradox
item.description: Despite a strong first quarter for startup funding, the Middle East’s venture ecosystem faces a unique paradox: The region’s sovereign wealth funds and family offices wield trillions of dollars and yet startups are struggling to access the funding they need to scale.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta, Christine Burke

item.title: Germany Gives Go-Ahead for Gas Drilling in Protected Marine Zone
item.description: Germany has given the green light for drilling as much as 13 billion cubic meters of natural gas at a protected marine site in the North Sea in a controversial step to bolster energy security.
item.dc:creator: Petra Sorge

media:content.media:description: Protestors demonstrate against the Borkum offshore gas project in Berlin, on Aug. 16, 2024. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Baidu Overhauls Search Engine With AI Features, Voice Function
item.description: Baidu Inc. is overhauling China’s most popular search engine with AI features and a voice function in its most sweeping revamp for years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Anderson, Zheping Huang

media:content.media:description: A display for Baidu Inc.'s Xiaodu AI chatbot during the Baidu Create AI Developer Conference in Wuhan, in April. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Robotics Startup Raises $105 Million Seed From US, China VCs
item.description: Genesis AI, a startup working on software for robots, has raised $105 million in a funding round with both US and Chinese backers — a rarity in an industry split along geopolitical lines.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: A humanoid robot at the Microsoft Corp. booth at the Hannover Messe 2025 trade fair in Hannover, Germany, on Monday, March 31, 2025. German inflation slowed more than anticipated in March, nearing the European Central Bank's 2% target as officials ponder whether to lower interest rates again at their next meeting or pause. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Amazon Hiring Executives for Asia Satellite Internet Push
item.description: Amazon.com Inc. is looking to hire government sales leads in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, laying the groundwork for its satellite internet business in East Asia.
item.dc:creator: Debby Wu, Matt Day, Cindy Wang

media:content.media:description: The launch the first batch of Kuiper satellites for Amazon. Photographer: Michael Cain/AP Photo

item.title: Polish Studio Behind ‘Silent Hill’ Remake Plans Original Games
item.description: Few expected a small Polish studio like Bloober Team SA to do justice to Silent Hill 2 with their remake of the survival horror classic. Yet the game turned out to be one of last year’s biggest hits, selling two million copies in just four months while winning award nominations and critical acclaim.
item.dc:creator: Mark Anderson, Zheping Huang

media:content.media:description: In Cronos: The New Dawn, monsters can merge with one another even after they’re slayed.
